review.title: Verb Physics: Relative Physical Knowledge of Actions and Objects
review.abstract: Learning commonsense knowledge from natural language text is nontrivial due to reporting bias: people rarely state the obvious, e.g., "My house is bigger than me." However, while rarely stated explicitly, this trivial everyday knowledge does influence the way people talk about the world, which provides indirect clues to reason about the world. For example, a statement like, "Tyler entered his house" implies that his house is bigger than Tyler.

metadata.title: VERB PHYSICS: Relative Physical Knowledge of Actions and Objects

sections.text: In this paper, we present an approach to derive relatively physical knowledge of actions and objects along five dimensions (e.g. size, weight and strength) from unstructured text in natural language. We take the acquisition of knowledge as a common conclusion on two closely related problems: learning (1) relatively physical knowledge of object pairs and (2) physical implications of actions when applied to these object pairs. Empirical results show that it is possible to extract knowledge of actions and objects from language and that common conclusions about different types of knowledge improve performance.

sections.heading: 2.1 Knowledge Dimensions
sections.text: In this work, we consider five dimensions of relative physical knowledge: size, weight, strength, stiffness, and speed. "Strength" in our work refers to the physical durability of an object (e.g. "diamond" is stronger than "glass"), while "stiffness" refers to the physical flexibility of an object (e.g. "glass" is stiffer than a "wire"). When looking at verb implications, size, weight, strength, and rigidity refer to semantics at the individual level; the relative properties that verbs imply in these dimensions are generally true. On the other hand, speed affects semantics at a level; their implicit relationships hold only during a window surrounding the verb (Carlson, 1977).

sections.heading: 3 Data and Crowdsourced Knowledge
sections.text: Action verbs: We select 50 classes of Levin verbs from both "alternative classes" and "verb classes" (Levin, 1993), corresponding to about 1100 unique verbs. We sort this list by frequency of occurrence in our frame patterns in the Google syntax Ngrams Corpus (Goldberg and Orwant, 2013), and select the top 100 verbs. Action frames: Figure 2 illustrates examples of action frame relationships. Because we look at implications via paired reasoning relationships for each frame, there are sometimes several frame relationships that we consider for a single frame. To enumerate the action frame relationships for each verb, we use syntactical patterns based on dependence, by extracting the core components (subject, verb, direct object, preposition object) of an action, the subject is assigned to an agent that leads the direct object to a topic, and the prepositional object to a target.

sections.heading: 3.1 Crowdsourcing Knowledge
sections.text: We collect human judgments about the implications of framework knowledge, which we use as a small set of seed knowledge (5%), a development set (45%), and a test set (50%).Crowd workers are given a framework template such as "x threw y" and are then asked to list a few plausible objects (including humans and animals) for the missing slots (e.g. x and y).This step consists of compressing them to think about the particular template; we do not use the objects they provide. We then ask them to evaluate the general relationship that the frame's arguments have with respect to all knowledge dimensions (size, weight, etc.).For each knowledge dimension or attribute, workers select an answer from (1) x > a, (2) x < a y, (3) x'a y, or (4) no general relationship between the frame and (3) no general relationship. We perform a similar crowdsourcing step for the set of object paths by asking each of the knowledge paths of 36d workers to compare each of the knowledge paths.

sections.heading: 4 Model
sections.text: As shown in Figure 3, the graph consists of several substrates (page-wide boxes) corresponding to different knowledge dimensions (illustrated are only three of them - Strength, Size, Weight - in brief).Each substrate consists of two types of subgraph: verb subgraphs and object subgraphs linked by factors that quantify the compatibility of action and object. Linkages between substrates are factors that model interdependencies across different knowledge dimensions. In the following, we describe each graph component.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: Metaphorical language: While our frame patterns are meant to capture action verbs, our templates also align with the senses of those verbs that can be used with abstract or metaphorical arguments rather than directly physical arguments. An example from the development group is "x contained y." While x and y can be real objects, the more abstract senses of "contained" could be y as a "forest fire" or even a "revolution." In these cases, x > size y as an abstract term is plausible: If a whole can contain a revolution, we might think that a whole could be "bigger" or "stronger" than the revolution.Error analysis: Examples 6-10 in Figure 4 highlight failures for the model. Example 6 shows a case where the comparison is nonsensical because "for" of course a purpose would be pursued ("he drove the car for work.") or a duration ("she drove the car for hours.") instead of a concrete object, the size of which the car is painted on, the example 7 is the car.

sections.heading: 7 Related work
sections.text: Several papers cover the gap between IE, knowledge base completion and learning common sense from texts. Previous work in these areas uses large amounts of text to try to extract general statements such as "A THING CAN BE READABLE" (Gordon et al., 2010) and frequencies of events (Gordon and Schubert, 2012). Our work focuses on specific areas of knowledge rather than general statements or event statistics and develops a framework-centric approach to circumventing report distortions (Angeli and Schubert, 2012). Other papers use a knowledge base and scores based on similarity to existing ones (Angeli and Manning, 2013; Li et al., 2016), or expand it by deriving new facts from unstructured texts with natural language inferences (Angeli and Manning, 2014). Zhang et al. (2017) predict the likelihood of deconstructed statements being extracted from a large text corpus.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: We presented a novel interpretation of verb-centric framework semantics to learn implicit physical knowledge latently embedded in verbs. Empirical results confirm that by modelling changes in physical attributes caused by verbs, together with objects that exhibit these properties, we are better able to infer new insights in both areas.

metadata.abstractText: Learning commonsense knowledge from natural language text is nontrivial due to reporting bias: people rarely state the obvious, e.g., “My house is bigger than me.” However, while rarely stated explicitly, this trivial everyday knowledge does influence the way people talk about the world, which provides indirect clues to reason about the world. For example, a statement like, “Tyler entered his house” implies that his house is bigger than Tyler. In this paper, we present an approach to infer relative physical knowledge of actions and objects along five dimensions (e.g., size, weight, and strength) from unstructured natural language text. We frame knowledge acquisition as joint inference over two closely related problems: learning (1) relative physical knowledge of object pairs and (2) physical implications of actions when applied to those object pairs. Empirical results demonstrate that it is possible to extract knowledge of actions and objects from language and that joint inference over different types of knowledge improves performance.
